Petkovic Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln Lincoln, NE 68588-0126, USA Received 12 April 1996; revised 16 June 1996; accepted 16 June 1996 Abstract The reactions of n-butane with hydrogen at 573 K were used as chemical probes to study the performance of platinum supported on tungstated zirconia (PtWZ) prepared by sequential impreg- nation of tungsten (W) and platinum (Pt) precursors. The effect of Pt and W loading and calcination and reduction temperatures on the n-butane isomerization activity and selectivity was determined. N-propylamine poisoning experiments show that the isomerization and homologation (C3 + C5) pathways are affected more dramatically than the hydrogenolysis routes because the former are exclusively acid-catalyzed reactions. Keywords: Platinum: Tungstated zirconia; n-Butane isomerization; Propylamine poisoning 1. Introduction Since sulfated zirconia catalysts promoted by noble metals are subjected to sulfate reduction and subsequent poisoning of the metallic function under reducing atmospheres [1,2], the Mo- and W-based oxoanions originally proposed by Hint and Arata [3,4] appear to be suitable candidates for isomerization of alkanes heavier than C4. The isomerization of n-butane can be used to gauge the 'practical' catalyst acidity i.e., as a chemical probe, because of the rather small number of product species that are formed in the 550-600 K temperature range. * Corresponding author. Petkouic /Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1996) 155-166 Disregarding hydrogenolysis reactions, the equilibrium conversion for the n- butane isomerization pathway is roughly 50% in that range [5], and as the molecular weight of linear hydrocarbons increases, thermodynamic calculations reveal that the equilibrium conversion toward branched paraffins would be heavily favored by the larger number of optical isomers and symmetry permuta- tions [6]. Thus, the lower activity of Pt supported on tungstated zirconia with respect to the sulfated material may not be a serious disadvantage for C6-C7 alkane isomerizations. Furthermore, according to a recent Exxon patent [7] and reports from the same group in scientific meetings [8-11], platinum supported on tungstated zirconia (PtWZ) is much more selective than its sulfated (PtSZ) counterpart for isomerization of heavier alkanes such as n-heptane. It is believed that the surface residence time of carbenium ions is much sorter in the case of PtWZ, thereby preventing /3-fission reactions that lead to acid-catalyzed crack- ing [10]. In a recent paper, we compared the performance of PtWZ prepared by two different methods in terms of their n-butane isomerization selectivity, coking rates and surface acidity [12]. We found that samples produced by sequential impregnation of ammonium metatungstate and hexachloroplatinic acid displayed high isomerization selectivity. In this paper, we report on the influence of the different preparation variables on catalyst performance, the effect of selective site poisoning and the apparent activation energies and preexponential factors for the different product molecules. The two preparation methods originally proposed needed to be examined in more detail, as we had explored only a few points in the preparation variables hyperspace. The effect of reduction and calcination temperatures, and of tungsten and platinum loadings is presented in this contribution. Such catalyst screening would in principle provide the reader with a more or less complete guide for the preparation of these materials. Based on an extensive literature search, no such studies are available in the journals literature. The work of Hino and Arata [3] represented the start point for both Iglesia and co-workers [7-11] and our group [12-14], but no catalyst optimiza- tion has yet been reported. PtWZ is then a promising system given its low tendency to form coke and its good isomerization activity and selectivity in the 200-300 range [12]. Since the overall stability (not the activity) of PtWZ is better than that of PtSZ, one should wonder whether PtWZ would still be sought as a potential alternative to other well-known systems such as those based on acidic mordenites in the 573 K range. In Fig. 5 of this manuscript, it will be seen that the selectivity of PtWZ toward isobutane is much higher than those reported for H-mordenite [15] and Pt/H-mordenite [16] under similar conditions. H-mordenite has a marked tendency to give n-butane disproportionation (C3 + C5) and cracking products around 300 [15], and so does Pt/H-mordenite [16]. On a mass basis, PtWZ renders comparable isobutane production rates. As a reference point, consider that at 13% total conversion, hydrogen:n-butane ratios of 0.25 and 271 G. Larsen, LM. Petkovic / Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1996) 155-166 157 reaction temperature, the selectivity of a 0.5 wt.-% Pt/H-mordenite catalyst toward isobutane was found to be only 9.5% [16]. Pt/H-mordenite is used commercially for isomerization of alkanes heavier than C4, but given the promising performance of PtWZ for the isomerization of n-heptane at high conversions as well (> 80% selectivity at 50% conversion, H~/n-C7 = 6.5,473 K, refs. [8] and [10]), a study on the preparation of PtWZ could expand our knowledge on this system. 2. Experimental The preparation of WZ and PtWZ by sequential W and Pt impregnation is described in detail elsewhere [12]. In brief, hydrous zirconia was obtained by conventional precipitation of zirconyl salts with ammonium hydroxide. The oven-dried hydrous zirconia was impregnated with solutions of ammonium metatungstate and hexachloroplatinic acid containing appropriate concentrations of both metals. The catalysts were crushed and sieved and the 20-45 mesh fraction was collected, then calcined at the chosen temperature for 1 h under a 0.8 1/min g cat. flow, and the calcination temperature was achieved by applying a 13/min ramp. The samples were subsequently reduced for 1 h at the selected temperature. For labeling purposes, we specify the wt.-% of either Pt or W immediately after the chemical symbol as subscripts, and the reduction and calcination temperatures (in ) as the label suffix and prefix respectively. For example, the 6 wt.-% W and 1.2 wt.-% Pt catalyst that had been calcined at 823 and reduced at 350 was labeled as 823-Ph.zW6Z-350. In our previous work, we characterized the 823-PtL2W~2Z-350 catalyst by temperature-pro- grammed oxidation, pyridine adsorption, chemisorption, X-ray diffraction and kinetics [12]. The present study reports on the performance of sets of catalysts (changing one variable at a time) in terms of their conversion and selectivity at a fixed temperature, partial pressures and catalyst mass in a packed-bed reactor. The goal was to narrow down the selection of calcination and reduction temperatures and W and Pt content to produce better isomerization catalysts for future studies, and to check whether a bifunctional mechanism is responsible for the isomerization of n-butane over PtWZ. The mass-flow and temperature-controlled atmospheric packed bed reaction system with on-line GC detection was described earlier [1]. The measurement of kinetic parameters required careful control of the product analysis scheme, by means of optimizing the detector sensitivity, column efficiency and sample size. We employed on-line FID detection (HP 5880A, six-port manual injection valve) and a 50 m methyl silicone capillary column from Hewlett-Packard. n-Propylamine 99.5% + was purchased from Fluka, and n-butane 99.9% and ultra-high purity hydrogen and air were supplied by Matheson. Hydrogen was passed through a commercial oxygen trap. Typically, 0.25 g of catalyst calcined 158 G. Larsen, L.M. Petkovic /Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1996) 155-166 and reduced in situ were exposed to a flowing mixture of 10 cc/min hydrogen and 15 cc/min n-butane at 300, resulting in 40.5 and 60.8 kPa partial pressures, respectively. The effect of partial pressures on conversion and selectivity was studied earlier and will not be discussed here [12]. To measure the kinetic parameters, an activity plateau was reached at the highest tempera- ture, followed by 8-10 decrements. For the n-propylamine poisoning experi- ments carried out over the 823-Pt0.3W6Z-350 catalyst, 1 /zl of liquid sample was injected via a septum assembly at the preheating section of the catalytic bed. 3. An appropriate calcination temperature range between 823 and 773 should provide maximum activity (Fig. 4). Hino and Arata [3] suggested the use of calcination temperatures around 827 to maximize the activity of Pt-free tungstated zirconia catalysts. In the case of PtSZ, it is well-known that the presence of surface sulfate both retards the crystallization process and stabilizes the tetragonal form of zirconia [17]. For example, the maximum n-butane isomerization activity of SZ is achieved after calcination at 600-620, the temperature at which the amount of tetragonal zirconia reaches a maximum [17]. On the other hand, the monoclinic form of SZ is known to be much less active for alkane isomerization [17]. Our studies indicate that calcination temper- atures higher than those for SZ are necessary for PtWZ samples to activate the W function, and it is the ability of this additive to retard the sintering of the support that also plays a role in catalyst activity. The BET surface areas of 823-Pt12W12-350 catalysts are around 45 m2/g after calcination, which are about one half order of magnitude higher than that of the tungsta-free sample calcined at the same temperature [13]. Still, the active phase formation process may be more complex than that of SZ. Using a combination of EXAFS and UV spectroscopy, Iglesia and co-workers [10,11] found that polynuclear tungsten oxide moieties are present after WZ activation. This is consistent with our G. A general overview of the product selectivities after 75 min time on stream (TOS) is presented in Fig. 5. The need for both Pt and W in the catalyst is apparent from this figure. In this sense, the catalyst is expected to be bifunc- tional, with the acid function participating in the isomerization (and to a small extent, fl-fission) of carbenium ions and the metal function providing the hydrogenation-dehydrogenation capacityIn addition, upon reduction of WZ and PtWZ catalysts and subsequent pyridine adsorption, we found that PtWZ preparations gave larger pyridinium ion IR signals [14]. This can be attributed to the Pt being able to activate the WZ acid function by hydrogen spillover. Note that, everything else kept constant, Figs. 1-5 show that PtWZ is roughly 2 times more active than WZ, which suggests that Pt also aids the acid site activation process. Thus, the better isomerization activity of PtWZ with respect to WZ is not merely due to the incorporation of a new, all-Pt-catalyzed isomerization pathwayThis will become apparent from the acid site poisoning experiments described below We had prepared a better dispersed catalyst by calcining the tungstated zirconia solid first, followed by impregnation of the dry powders with an ether solution of Pt(acac)2 and finally calcining the Pt-loaded material to 500 [12]. Such material showed high hydrogenolysis selectivities but given its higher coke 162 G. Larsen, L.M. Petkovic / Applied Catalysis A: General 148 (1996) 155-166 formation resistance, we chose to study the effect of W loading to see whether the selectivity could be improved (suffix 'Aco' in Fig. 5). Fig. 5 shows that the production of hydrogenolysis species in these catalysts is still higher than those prepared by the co-calcination method. Since the sequential calcination method gives CO/Pt dispersions three times higher than those of the co-calcined samples [12], it appears that all-Pt-catalyzed hydrogenolysis becomes significant as the Pt surface area increases, without adding any benefit to the yield of isobutane. In general, the selectivity of PtWZ catalysts toward isomerization at low conversions is very good. Previous comparisons with a Pt/A1203 catalyst showed that the latter preferentially catalyzes the hydrogenolysis pathway under the same conditions [12]. Of all preparation variables, it appears that the calcination temperature is most critical (see Figs. 4 and 5). In this sense, PtWZ resembles PtSZ in that this variable plays the major role in creating the active isomerization sites. A key difference between the two is that small aggregates or crystallites of a WO3-1ike form are present when PtWZ becomes active, in light of UV spectroscopy [10] and XRD [12] evidence, but isolated sulfate centers are generally accepted to be responsible for the formation of the acid function in PtSZ. Recently, we have conducted pulse experiments using labeled n-butanes, CH3-(CH2)2-13CH3 (1 *C4) and 13CH3-(CH2)2-13CH3 (1-4.C4), and con- cluded that a bimolecular mechanism is responsible for n-butane isomerization and homologation [18-20]. Small but detectable amounts of pentanes (Fig. 5) are consistent with the proposal of a C ~- open cation as originally proposed by Bearez et al. [21] for the isomerization of n-butane over H-mordenite. However, it is apparent from Fig. 5 that the homologation pathway is much slower than the isomerization channel in the case of PtWZ, which is a desirable feature from a practical viewpoint. We mentioned earlier that homologation (as well as hydrocracking) of n-butane is more important in H-mordenite [15] and Pt/H- mordenite [16] catalysts than in PtWZ. Fig. 6 shows how the injection of 1 /zl of n-propylamine (N/W ratio: 0.15) poisons the production of the different reaction species over 823-Pto.3W6-350, once the system had achieved steady state. To generate an activity plateau, we first reacted n-butane over the catalyst for one half hour under N2 :H2 :n-Ca flow ratios of 15:10:15 (total flow: 88 cc/min g cat.). Then, we interrupted the inert gas flow only. It appears that this increase in hydrogen partial pressure causes an activity plateau to be reached in a short time. From Fig. 6, it is apparent that the production of isomerization and homologation species is completely suppressed after injection of the base molecule, which is consistent with the proposal of a bifunctional mechanism, but hydrogenolysis species are still being detected. Unlike the pentanes and isobutane, propane is expected to be generated by both all-Pt-catalyzed hydrogenolysis and homologation, and it is the former that completely takes over the C3 production after the poisoning of the acid function. The small time lag in the propane production decay shown in Fig. 6 may be due to the fact that this molecule is also a product of n-propylamine hydrogenolysis. Still, the residual methane and propane production is expected to be a Pt-cata- lyzed reaction since this is the only catalytic function that survived the n-pro- pylamine poisoning process. Earlier, by comparing the catalytic behavior of Pt/A1203, Pt/ZrO2 and 823-Pt1.2W12-350 catalysts, we proposed that while isomerization (and homologation) was expected to occur exclusively on the acid sites, the formation of lighter hydrocarbons in the presence of hydrogen took place primarily on the Pt function [12]. It is interesting to point out that base amounts much smaller than stoichiometric are sufficient to completely eliminate the isomerization and homologation activities. Thus, this favors the idea that there is not one acid site per every Wn+ center in 823-Pto.3W6-350, a fact that was discussed in more detail above. Rather high calcination temperatures are necessary to activate the W function (see Fig. 4), and one is forced to compromise among a few variables, including Pt and W loading. If this were the case, the activation energy for methane formation could be a convolution of at least two different pathways, namely direct hydrogenolysis of n-C4, and secondary hydrogenolysis of i-C4. Similarly, propane appears to be produced by both hydrogenolysis and homologation. To test this idea we also measured the kinetic parameters for methane production in the 0.1-0.15% conversion range under the same temperature and pressure conditions but after n-PrNH2 poisoning (Fig. 7 and Table 1). At this lower overall conversion required for minimizing the formation of methane as a secondary product, ethane and propane production were below the detection limit. We expect ethane to be formed from n-butane on the Pt function, just as methane would be after acid site poisoning. It is interesting to notice that the preexponential factors for these two cases (methane after poisoning and ethane before poisoning) are in the same order of magnitude, suggesting they may in principle take place over similar active sites. Of course, such an assumption should still be taken with caution because the preexponential factor is a convolution of the number of active sites and the entropy difference between the activated complex and the reactant. As a reference point to our n-butane kinetic results, our hydrogenolysis activation energies are comparable to those reported by Leclercq et al. [22] for Pt/A1203 catalysts. These authors found values around 125 and 160 kJ/mol for terminal and internal C-C bond rupture, respectively. On the other hand, in the absence of surface acidity such as in the Pt/C catalysts studied by Rodrlguez- Reinoso et al. [23], the n-butane isomerization activation energy is in the order of 170-210 kJ/mol (H/Pt- 0.08-0.51). This is in fact what we observed for the bifunctional PtWZ catalysts in Table 1. Our proposed reaction scheme is presented in Fig. 8. The open octyl cation and the pathways leading to homologation and isomerization products have been proposed in light of our isotopic labeling results [18]. Other intermediates and routes leading to pentanes and isobutane have been discarded since they should have required the formation of triply labeled primary products (which were in fact not observed), or had at least one methyl or hydride shift step resulting in the formation of less substituted carbenium ions. Here, our addition to this scheme (originally reported in ref. [18]) consists of the incorporation of the hydrogenolysis processes, recognizing that secondary formation of lighter alka- nes from primary products should not be ignored. For simplicity, we have not included the Pt-catalyzed hydrogenation-dehydrogenation pathways which are of course necessary to (a) produce trace amounts of butenes as precursors for carbocations and (b) to hydrogenate the olefins resulting from /3-fission back to alkanes. In summary, we have studied how a number of preparation variables affect the catalysis of n-C4/H2 reactions over PtWZ, and showed how the presence of acid sites is essential to increase the selectivity toward isomerization. In future studies, we will compare our best PtWZ catalysts with conventional alkane isomerization materials in terms of activity and selectivity using higher molecu- lar weight alkanes. 166 G. Petkovic Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, NE 68588-0126, USA ∗ Corresponding author. Tel.: (+1-402) 472-9805; fax: (+1-402) 472-6989 The reactions of n-butane with hydrogen at 573 K were used as chemical probes to study the performance of platinum supported on tungstated zirconia (PtWZ) prepared by sequential impregnation of tungsten (W) and platinum (Pt) precursors. The effect of Pt and W loading and calcination and reduction temperatures on the n-butane isomerization activity and selectivity was determined. N-propylamine poisoning experiments show that the isomerization and homologation (C3 + C5) pathways are affected more dramatically than the hydrogenolysis routes because the former are exclusively acid-catalyzed reactions.
